contentrichtext.text: {{nosources|date=August 2012}} {{For|the main article about the controller|Parallel ATA}} The '''Ultra DMA''' ('''UDMA''') interface was the fastest method used to transfer data between the computer (through the [[Advanced Technology Attachment|ATA]] [[controller (computing)|controller]]) and an [[Advanced Technology Attachment|ATA]] device until [[Serial ATA]]. UDMA took over from [[Single word DMA|Single]]/[[Multiword DMA]] as the choice of interface between ATA devices and the computer. There are 8 different UDMA modes ranging from 0 to 6 for ATA, 0 to 7 for CompactFlash), each with its own timing. {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center" |+Transfer Modes ! Mode || Number ||Also called||Maximum transfer<br/>rate (MB/s)|| Defining standard |- | rowspan=8 | Ultra DMA | 0 || || 16.7||[[ATA-4]] |- | 1 || || 25.0||[[ATA-4]] |- | 2 ||Ultra ATA/33|| 33.3||[[ATA-4]] |- | 3 || || 44.4||[[ATA-5]] |- | 4 ||Ultra ATA/66|| 66.7||[[ATA-5]] |- | 5 ||Ultra ATA/100|| 100||[[ATA-6]] |- | 6 ||Ultra ATA/133|| 133||[[ATA-7]] |- | 7 || Ultra ATA/167 || 167 || [[CompactFlash]] 6.0<ref>[http://compactflash.org/2010/cf-6-0-introduces-industry-leading-performance-and-feature-enhancements/ CompactFlash 6.0 Introduction]</ref> |} == See also == * [[Programmed input/output|PIO]] - The first interface type used between devices (mainly hard disks) and the computer. * [[Advanced Technology Attachment|ATA]] * [[Parallel ATA]] * [[Serial ATA]] ==References== <references /> [[Category:AT Attachment]]
